description: On February 1, 2020, the government of Kerala, India issued guidelines to the general public in Malayalam, warning against false news being spread about the coronavirus - such as drinking hot water or salt water as a treatment. The public was instructed not to forward such messages, and instead follow and spread only the advisories issued by the Department of Health.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: A wave of misinformation and rumour on Covid-19 making rounds among the public in India on 10th March which had forced the Indian Government to issue an advisory.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
India, 11 March 2020, In exercise of powers conferred under 'The Haryana Epidemic Disease Act 1897, The Governor of Haryana is pleased to issue following regulations regarding COVID-19 (Corona Virus Disease 2019):
No person/Institution/Organization will use any print or electronic media for information regarding COVID-19 without prior permission of Health Department, Haryana. This is to avoid spread of any rumour or unauthenticated information regarding COVID-19. In case, any person/Institution/Organization is found indulging such activity, it will be treated as a punishable offence under these regulations.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
India, 11 March 2020, In exercise of powers conferred under 'The Haryana Epidemic Disease Act 1897, The Governor of Haryana is pleased to issue following regulations regarding COVID-19 (Corona Virus Disease 2019):
No private Laboratories have been authorized to take or test samples for COVID-19 in the state of Haryana. All such samples will be collected as per Guidelines of Govt. of India and these will be sent to designated labs by the District Nodal Officer appointed by Health Department, Haryana.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: India, 13 March 2020, In exercise of powers conferred under section 2,3 & 4 of The Epidemic Disease Act,1897, the Administrator, Union Territory of Chandigarh  is pleased to issue following regulations regarding COVID-19 (Corona Virus Disease 2019):No private Laboratories have been authorized to take or test samples for COVID-19 in the state of Haryana. All such samples will be collected as per Guidelines of Govt. of India and these will be sent to designated labs by the Nodal Officer of designated hospital of Department of Health and Family Welfare, Chandigarh Administration.

The memo originated from the National Government and was copied for circulation by Goan Government.

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On 20th March 2020, the Government of India issued an advisory, urging all social media platforms to initiate awareness campaigns, remove misinformation, and promote authentic information related to the virus. The government wrote to top social media companies including Facebook,
Google-owned YouTube, Twitter, TikTok and ShareChat to sanitise their
platforms. The government asked social media platforms to make users aware not to upload or circulate false news concerning coronavirus.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 21st March 2020, Narendra Modi, India’s Prime Minister, announced that citizens in the country can text a WhatsApp bot — called MyGov Corona Helpdesk — to get instant authoritative answers to their coronavirus queries such as the symptoms of the viral disease and how they could seek help. The policy was announced to create awareness about the coronavirus pandemic and has urged social media services to tackle the spread of misinformation on their platforms.
The bot was built by Mumbai-based firm Haptik Technologies and the information is being provided by the nation’s Ministry of Health.
“The ‘MyGov Corona Helpdesk’ has been engineered to fight rumours, educate the masses and bring a sense of calm to the current chaos-like situation.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Following up on the Supreme Court of India’s observations of the panic created by Fake News leading to the mass movement of migrant labourers, Secretary, Union Ministry for Home Affairs (MHA), Shri Ajay Kumar Bhalla on 1st April 2020 has written to all States/UTs to take effective measures to fight Fake News. It has been communicated that the Government of India is creating a web-portal for people to verify facts and unverified news promptly. States/UTs have been requested to create a similar mechanism at their level for issues relating to them.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 1st April 2020, Supreme Court of India issued an office memorandum directing Govt of India to take action under the Section 54 of Disaster Management Act 2005 against people who publish, print or telecast any fake news on the Novel Coronavirus. The section provides punishment to a person who makes or circulates a false alarm leading to panic and such person shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to one year or with a fine.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 04-20-2020,in Delhi province in India,It has come to the notice that there are large numbers of social media messages regarding functioning of Hospitals of Government of NCT of Delhi are floating around.
The concerned hospital needs to either rebut the information or take corrective action to avoid reoccurrence of such incidences.
Medical Superintendent, Medical Directors and Director of all Hospitals of Government of NCT of Delhi are directed to create a media cell, who should monitor social media, news media and immediately react to such news/information so that correct position is presented before people.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: India, 1 May, 2020, The Administrator mentioned that it has come to the notice that some media organizations’ are reporting wrong information regarding the number of COVID cases, thereby creating panic in the minds of people. He warned that such Fake News should be avoided, otherwise, necessary action will be taken under relevant legal provisions.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On 14th June 2020, India along with 12 other countries, has decided to lead an initiative aimed at spreading fact-based content to counter misinformation on the coronavirus, with over 130 nations endorsing the global call to fight the "infodemic" relating to Covid-19 pandemic. 
India's permanent mission to the UN said that it supported the UN Communications response initiative '#VERIFIED' and "calls for global action to fight infodemic in times of COVID-19".
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description:
In a letter written to Principal Secretary/Secretary-in-charge of Tribal Development Department of these States, the Ministry has said that in view of prevailing sensitive health conditions affecting community health due to Covid-19 (Corona Virus), it has been seen that at various places local administration have issued directions to take preventive measures including declaration of vacations to avoid spreading of infection. In certain cases, the directions issued permits completion of the scheduled annual examinations.

In view of the contingent situation, the Ministry of Tribal Affairs has issued the following instructions in respect of the Eklavya Model Residential Schools for rescheduling of Holidays in Eklavya Model Residential Schools (EMRS) and Eklavya Model Day Boarding Schools (EMDBS) funded by the Ministry of Tribal Affairs :

Summer Holidays to be advanced as a special case and schools to remain shut from 21.03.2020 till 25.05.2020 (65 days) or till further orders whichever is earlier.
Till such time, entry of outsiders into the campus is completely banned.
Students appearing in Board Examinations and attending special classes may be retained with due care in the campus. Such students appearing in Board examinations may be sent home soon after completion of respective papers.
Special drive may be taken to sanitize the school campus including the academic block, hostels and other common areas.

description: India, 14 April, 2020, the Summer Vacation has been preponed and scheduled from 15th April to 14th May, the Education Department has decided to declare the result of Classes IX and XI. The result criteria shall be circulated to all the Govt Schools in a couple of days. Subsequently the result would be declared on 20 th April. The result would be displayed on the website of the respective schools. It would also be conveyed to students through text messages and Whatsapp messages. The parents or students need not come to school for the same. They can call on the helpline numbers already circulated.

description:
Taking into consideration the academic interest of large number of students, it has been
decided to grant exemption to conduct Board Examinations for Classes 10th and 12th from the
lockdown measures, tweeted Union Minister for Home Affairs, Shri Amit Shah.
As opening of schools had been prohibited under the guidelines on lockdown measures, the
annual board examinations being conducted by State Education Boards/ CBSE/ ICSE etc. for
classes 10th and 12th had been suspended. Requests were received from State Governments
and CBSE for conducting the Board examinations.
Considering this the Union Ministry for Home Affairs (MHA) has written to all States/UTs
detailing the conditions to be followed for conducting the examinations. These are:
• In Containment zones, no examination centre would be permitted.
• Wearing of face masks by teachers. staff and students would be mandatory.
• There should be provision of thermal screening and sanitizer at the centres and social
distancing in all the examination centres.
• In view of examination to be conducted by different Boards, their examination
schedules should be staggered.
• Special buses may be arranged by the States and UTs for transportation of the
students to the examination centres.

New Delhi, May 20, 2020.

description: Solapur district administration has imposed curfew in Pandharpur and 10 surrounding villages from the night of November 24 to November 26 and cancelled the annual gathering of Kartiki Ekadashi. All the vehicles going towards Pandharpur would be stopped at the entry point of Solapur district. The administration has also banned taking a holy dip in the Chandrabhaga river from Saturday to December 31. All commercial, religious and other establishments have been issued notices not to offer shelter to anyone coming from outside. The MSRTC’s bus services would remain suspended on November 25 and 26.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country

description: On 21 December 2020, the Chief Minister of Maharashtra State Government in India announced a seven-hour night curfew in all municipal corporation areas of the state. The night curfew, from 23:00 to 06:00 hrs will come into force from 22 December 2020 till 6 January 2021. The curfew will cover establishments and movement of people and vehicles on roads. Emergency services such as public transportation and supply of milk and vegetables will be allowed. Large gatherings, parties, functions, shops, hotels and theatres will mandatorily end or shutdown their shutters by 23:00 hrs and no more than 5 people can assemble outside during the specified curfew hours. The state government has advised people to reach home before 23:00 hrs and not step out till 06:00 hrs except in case of an emergency.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
India, 18 April, 2020, WHEREAS vide order No.40-3/2020-DM-I(A), dated 24103/2020, the Union Home Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India had issued an order under Section 10(2)(1) of Disaster Management Act, stipulating lockdown measures for containment of COVID-19 in the country. 
WHEREAS the same order was extended vide letter dated 14/04/2020 to remain in force till 3rd May, 2020 all over the country. 
WHEREAS vide order dated 15/04/2020 it was stipulated by Government of India that additional activities allowed to mitigate hardship of public will not be applicable in containment' zone (except those activities, as are specifically permissible under guidelines of Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India.) 
WHEREAS vide letter No.Z-21020/16/2020-PH, dated 15/04/2020, the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare included Chandigarh in the official list of HOTSPOTS (RED ZONE) in the country. 
WHEREAS the cases of outbreak of COVID-19 in Chandigarh are seen as scattered, non-contiguous and sporadic in nature and spread 
WHEREAS in consultation with the medical experts, the Chandigarh Administration is of considered opinion that the entire city of Chandigarh needs to be kept under stricter measures for containment of spread of COVID-19. 
Therefore, the undersigned, in his capacity as Chairperson of State Executive Committee of State Disaster Management Authority hereby declares the entire Union Territory of Chandigarh as "CONTAINMENT ZONE.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
₹ 2,000 Fine For Not Wearing Mask In Delhi, Up From 500, To Tackle Covid
Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal has announced a steep ₹ 2,000 fine -- up from the current ₹ 500 -- for those caught without masks, to help control the coronavirus surge that's in its third week. The Chief Minister also appealed to all political parties and social organizations to distribute masks at public places in Delhi.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: The government of Assam in India is contact tracing individuals who tested positive for COVID-19 by identifying at least 5 individuals outside of the immediate family of the infected person. These individuals need to participate in a rapid antigen test and RT-PCR test beginning 8th January 2021.
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time

description:
Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) writes to States/UTs to ensure smooth Disbursal of Money to beneficiaries of PMGKY during 21-day Lockdown to fight COVID-19. 
- The Department of Financial Services, Ministry of Finance had issued detailed guidelines on the disbursal of money to beneficiaries of Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Yojana (PM-GKY) through banks, 21-day lockdown to fight COVID-19.
- In pursuance of these guidelines, Secretary, Union Ministry for Home Affairs (MHA), Shri Ajay Kumar Bhalla has written to all States/UTs requesting them to take all necessary measures to ensure smooth disbursal of money to the beneficiaries of PM-GKY, while observing norms of social distancing.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) writes to States to give special attention on keeping the supply of Medical Oxygen smooth and hassle-free across the country.
- As part of maintaining a smooth supply of essential items in the country, Union Home Secretary, Shri Ajay Kumar Bhalla has written to all State Chief Secretaries to give special attention on keeping the supply of medical oxygen smooth and hassle-free. 
- It has been emphasized upon as there is a critical need to maintain adequate supply of medical oxygen in the country in the wake of COVID-19 Pandemic and medical oxygen is also included in the national list and WHO's a list of essential medicines.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
India, 18 April, 2020, As per the revolving situation, with the surge in the number of cases there is a need
of hour to maintain the diagnostic data (RDT/ RT-PCR method) on digital platform for quick
response to COVID-19 epidemic.
In reference to the above, Government of India has issued direction (D.O.No.7 (13)/2020-NHM-I
dated l6th April 2020) regarding the maintenance of diagnostic data (RDT/ RT-PCR method)
through portal and apps. As per this direction, details of Collection Centres and Rapid Testing
Centres should be entered in the NIC portal.
Hence in compliance of the above mentioned orders, you are directed to identify the
collection centres at your respective districts with immediate effect.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
In Delhi province in India, it was noted that many hospitals were denying treatment and demanding Covid test before treatments being administered.In view of this ,all the Hospitals/Clinics, especially those in
private sectors, are hereby directed to remain functional and ensure that anyone needing any essential critical services including dialysis, blood transfusion,chemotherapy and institutional deliveries, is not denied such service.
Non Compliance will be viewed seriously and action as per provisions of law,including cancellation of the registration of the defaulter hospital/nursing home will be initiated without further notice.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
In Delhi province in India,Psychiatric Social Counselling Services are available through tele-Counselling for Doctors, Nurses, other Health care workers and all other front lineworkers, under the aegis of Government of Delhi.
This services named "Samarthan" by IHBAS, with support of Delhi Psychiatric Society(DPS) and in collaboration with the Delhi Medical Council (DMC) and Delhi MedicalAssociation (DMA), Senior expert Psychiatrists from the Government and Private Sectors have
offered to provide voluntary services for Tele-Counselling, with back-up services in person, as and when required, from IHBAS emergency services round the clock, from the Psychiatry Department of the COVID hospitals or their linked hospitals
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
Delhi Disaster Management Authority accepted the recommendations of the committee, under Dr V K Paul, member, NITI Ayog for fixing reasonable rate for COVID test performed by private labs in NCT of Delhi, fixing rates at Rs 2400/- for each COVID_RTPCR test for the sample collected by the Government. It was further, decided that the rates recommended are maximum chargeable for sample collected by any facility whether in Government or in private.

Accordingly, the rates for COVID RT-PCR test in Delhi has been fixed at Rs. 2400/-per test inclusive of GST /Taxes, if any, cost involved in picking & transportation of samples,documentation and reporting with immediate effect.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
Delhi Disaster Management Authority accepted the recommendations of the committee, under Dr V K Paul, member, NITI Ayog for fixing reasonable rate for COVID test performed by private labs in NCT of Delhi, fixing rates at Rs 2400/- for each COVID_RTPCR test for the sample collected by the Government. It was further, decided that the rates recommended are maximum chargeable for sample collected by any facility whether in Government or in private.

Accordingly, the rates for COVID RT-PCR test in Delhi has been fixed at Rs. 2400/-per test inclusive of GST /Taxes, if any, cost involved in picking & transportation of samples,documentation and reporting with immediate effect. UPDATE: The original price of RT PCR test was fixed to be Rs 2400 which has been reduced and fixed to a rate of 800.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
Indian Ministry of Health and Family Welfare on 31 Aug 2020 has decided to deploy high level Central teams to four States of Uttar Pradesh, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, and Odisha seeing a sudden surge in the number of COVID cases and high mortality rate.
The teams will support the State efforts towards strengthening containment, surveillance, testing and efficient clinical management of the positive cases, timely diagnosis and follow up and will comprise of an epidemiologist and a public health expert.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
link: 12-04-2020_Health Ministry to rush Central teams to UP, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, and Odisha

description:
The state of Assam in India establishes a payment system for the collection of plasma from a government blood bank. Hospitals will need to pay 10,000 rupees per unit of plasma acquired from government-run blood banks for the use of blood transfusions starting 5th October 2020. 
 UPDATE: The original policy required hospitals to bear the fee of the plasma apheresis kit, but the updated policy requires hospitals to also pay 10,000 rupees for every unit of plasma acquired from a government blood bank.
type_text: The government is establishing a price that hospitals will need to pay when acquiring materials from a government blood bank for a covid-19 patient.

description:
All health care facilities are required to carry out compulsory 'Rapid Antigen Detection Testing' of following high risk group of individuals who visit their facility:
1. All individuals/patients with ILI symptoms
2. All patients admitted with SARI
3. All asymptomatic patients admitted or seeking admission of following high-risk group:
a. Patients undergoing Chemotherapy
b. Immuno suppressed patient including HIV+
c. Patients with Malignant disease
d. Transplant Patients
e. Elderly patients (>65 years of age) with co-morbidities
4. All asymptomatic patients undergoing aerosol generating interventions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
In Delhi province in India it was decided that, all health care facilities are required to carry out compulsory 'Rapid Antigen Detection
Testing' of following high risk group of individuals who visit their facility:
1. All individuals/patients with ILi symptoms
2. All patients admitted with SARI
3. All asymptomatic patients admitted or seeking admission of following high-risk group:
a. Patients undergoing Chemotherapy
b. Immunosuppressed patient including HIV+
c. Patients with Malignant disease
d. Transplant Patients
e. Elderly patients (>65 years of age) with co-morbidities
4. All asymptomatic patients undergoing aerosol generating interventions
from 05th July 2020.

description:
India, In exercise of powers conferred under 'The Haryana Epidemic Disease Act 1897, following directions are hereby issued in the State of Haryana with immediate effect:
Restaurant to ensure hand washing protocol and proper cleanliness of frequently touched surfaces. Physical distancing of 1 meter between tables be maintained and open air settings be encouraged wherever practical with adequate distancing.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Advisory for all Government offices of all Departments to prevent spread of
COVID-19. Following steps are be taken by all Departments in their
respective offices at each level to prevent the spread of COVID-19:
i. Provide Hand Sanitizers and Hand washing facility in the premises of the office
and ensure use of the same by all employees.
ii. Ensure regular sanitization/disinfection of the office, especially of doors, railings. floor and other contact points.
iii. Display IEC material (like Do's/Don'ts) as advised by Health Department at prominent places for awareness of employees regarding COVID- 19.
iv. If any employee is having flu like symptoms, refer him/her to the nearest health
care facilities.
v. All Departments should mobilize their own resources and utilize their own funds for procurement of sanitizers, disinfectants etc. and display of IEC material.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
COVID-19 Guidelines for Employers and employees of Chandigarh Administration.
Cleaning offices and public places where there are suspected or confirmed cases of COVID-19, all surfaces that person has come into contact with, must be cleaned including: 
a)All surfaces and objects which ae visibly contaminated with body fluids.
b)All potentially contaminated high contact areas such as  toilets, door handles, telephones.
c)Public areas where symptomatic individual has passed through and spent minimal time in (such as corridors) but which are not visibly contaminated with body fluids do not need to be specially cleaned and disinfected.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
India, 16 March 2020, A review meeting held under the Chairpersonship of Worthy Chief Secretary Haryana on 16.03.2020, following steps are be taken by Malls to prevent the spread of COVID-19:
i. To use Thermal Scanners at the entry points with immediate effect and if any person is found having flu like symptoms, he must be referred to nearest health care facilities.
ii. To frequently do sanitization/disinfection in the premises, especially of doors handles, railings, floors and other contact points.
iii. Provide Hand Sanitizers and Hand washing facility in the premises for general public and also ensure use of the same by employees working in all shops.
iv. Display IEC material (like Do's/Don'ts) as advised by Health Department at prominent places for awareness of public and employees regarding COVID- 19.
v. If any employee is having flu like symptoms, refer him/her to the nearest health care facilities.
vi. All malls should mobilize their own resources and utilize their own funds for procurement of sanitizers, disinfectants etc. and display of IEC material.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Corona Virus Disease 2019(COVID-19) Guidelines to the Management of Factory/Establishments.
In view of prevailing epidemic situation Corona Virus Disease 2019(COVID-19) across the world and in country, THE FOLLOWING guidelines shall be strictly followed in all factories/Establishments in State of Haryana:-
a)Promote frequent and thorough hand washing, by providing workers, customers and worksite visitors with a place to wash their hands. If soap and running water are not immediately available, provide alcohol based hand rubs containing at least 60% alcohol.
b)Encourage workers to stay at home if they are sick and call state helpline no. and other guidelines included.

description:
India, 29 March 2020, DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC RELATIONS
CHANDIGARH ADMINISTRATION.
It is brought out for the information of all that in wake of COVID-19 Pandemic, the wholesaler, retailers, shopkeepers are advised to maintain hygiene at work place and take following measures:
1. To maintain Social Distancing. Prepare marked circles/squares in such a way that a minimum of 1 meter distance is maintained between any 2 customers.
2. Sanitize every customer by way of hand sanitizer before entering the shop and on exiting the shop.
3. Avoid over-crowding. Limit the number of shoppers. This can be done by letting customers into the store progressively.
4. Put at least one person on duty for ensuring social distance.
5. You shall keep a hand sanitizer in place for sanitizing each customer.
6. Provide a Mask, Hand Wash and Sanitizer to the staffers and work force.
7. To ensure hand washing protocol and proper cleanliness of frequently touched surfaces.
8. Hygiene and physical distancing has to be maintained. Shaking hands and hugging as a matter of greeting is to be avoided.
9. Encourage Home Delivery, e-payment.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: India, 1 June, 2020, To avoid and pre-empt the spread of the COVID-19 Pandemic, the following will be the guidelines to be followed by all Hair Salon/ Barber-shops operating within the territorial jurisdiction of Union Territory of Chandigarh.  Guidelines for Opening / operating Hair Salon /Barber-shop: Thermal temperature measuring equipment will be compulsory at entry. Temperature will be measured of all visitors /workers. Hand Sanitizers will be available at entry for clients /staff. Separate disposable towel /paper sheet shall be used for each client without any fail.  In case towels are to be reused separate towel to be used for each customer and used towel shall be disinfected by 0.1% sodium hypochlorite solution. H. All equipments shall be sanitized after each use on client using 0.5% solutions of Sodium Hypochlorite. It is better to keep multiple sets so as to use other while one set is getting disinfected. FlOor/common areas / handrails /door-knobs /work table/slab and frequently touching surfaces /objects must be disinfected with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution at least 3-4 time a day. Carpets and rugs are not allowed. Floor must be cleaned regularly and frequently throughout the Service delivery timings. Magazines, Newspapers and reading material may be avoided. Remotes of TV etc shall also be handled by only assigned person and should be disinfected regularly.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) orders the restricting movement of migrants and strict enforcement of lockdown measures. 
-State/Union territories asked to ensure adequate arrangements of temporary shelters, and the provision of food, etc. 
-The migrant people, who have moved out to reach their home states/ home towns, must be kept in the nearest shelter by the respective State/ Union Territory government. 
-All the employers shall make payment of wages of their workers, at their workplaces, on the due date, without any deduction. 
- Wherever the workers, including the migrants, are living in the rented accommodation, the landlords of the properties shall not demand payment of rent for a period of one month. 
- If any landlord is forcing laborers and students to vacate their premises, they will be liable for action under the act.

description: Maharashtra government on Monday, November 23 made it mandatory for people coming from four states - Delhi, Rajasthan, Goa and Gujarat to carry a Covid-negative report. All passengers travelling in flights from these states will have to produce negative RT-PCR report on landing at airports in Maharashtra. The test should have been done 72 hrs prior to the scheduled journey whereas the passengers travelling in trains from these four states will have to produce the negative report obtained 96 hours prior to the journey on arrival and for those coming by roads will have to undergo screening at border check posts. Also, people with symptoms will have to undergo an antigen test. If found positive, the traveller will have to get admitted to the Covid centre by bearing the cost of treatment.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
Jammu: The Jammu and Kashmir administration on Sunday ordered the shutdown of all establishments except those providing essential services and commodities across the Union Territory till March 31.The Commissioner  said the shutdown was necessary to prevent the spread of COVID-19 pandemic and break the transmission chain of the virus.

"...it is necessary to enforce social distancing, i.e., preventing/minimizing close contact between people, therefore, Deputy Commissioners/District Magistrates shall issue orders under section 144 CrPC and also under the Disaster Management Act 2005 (both Acts) to shutdown all establishments except those providing essential commodities/services in their districts from Sunday 22 March, 2020 (08.00 PM) till Tuesday, the 31st March, 2020 (06.00 pm)," the letter said.

description:
On 03-22-2020, Delhi province in India announced a lockdown in the whole of territorial jurisdiction of NCT of Delhi from 0600 hrs on
Monday, 23rd March, 2020 to midnight of Tuesday, 31 st March, 2020, stipulating the
following restrictions:
a. No public transport services including operation of private buses, taxis, autorickshaws, rickshaws and e-rickshaws etc. shall be permitted. Only DTC buses shall
operate at not more than 25% capacity to cater to personnel engaged in essential
services.
b. All shops, commercial establishments, factories, workshops, offices, godowns,
weekly bazaars etc. shall close their operations.
c. The motorable and unmotorable borders ofNCT of Delhi with the neighbouring states
of Haryana and Uttar Pradesh shall be sealed.
d. Movement of inter-state buses/trains/metro (DMRC) shall be suspended.
e. All domestic/international flights arriving to Delhi during this period shall be
suspended.
f. Construction activity of any kind shall be suspended.
g. All religious places of any denomination shall be closed.
h. People are required to stay at home and come out only for basic services (as
enumerated below) within the vicinity of their residences while strictly following the
social distancing guidelines issued earlier.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
Two-Day Shutdown Enforced In Burla NAC.
Amid rising COVID-19 cases, Shutdown restrictions have been imposed for two days in some areas of Sambalpur Municipal Corporation (SMC) from Thursday.
Burla area (from Ward-3 to Ward-7) under the SMC, barring the VIMSAR campus, are under complete shutdown during this period. description:
India, 13 April, 2020, According to guidelines there are three types of COVID Dedicated
Facilities which are as under:-
(1) COVID Care Center (CCC):
o For cases clinically assigned as mild I very mild cases / suspect cases.
o Facilities can be setup in hostels, hotels, schools, stadiums, lodges etc. (Functional
Hospitals as last resort)
o Separate areas for suspect and confirmed cases is mandatory.
o Attempt to be made to provide individual rooms for suspect cases.
. Every such Facility must be mapped to one or more COVID Dedicated Health Center (DCHC) or COVID Dedicated Hospital (DCH) for referral.
o Basic Life Support Ambulance (BSLA) with sufficient oxygen support 24*7 to be available.
o HR may be roped-in from AYUSH doctors. (Training protocols and trained pool available).
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
India, 13 April, 2020, Dedicated COVID Health Centre (DCHC):
o For cases clinically assigned as moderate.
o Full hospital or a block of hospital.
o Private hospitals also can be designated.
o Hospital will have separate areas for suspect and confirmed cases.
. Hospital to have beds with assured oxygen support
. Every such facility to be mapped with one or more Dedicated COVID Hospital .(DCH)
o Basic Life Support Ambulance(BlSA) with sufficient oxygen support for ensuring safe transport
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
India, 13 April, 2020, Dedicated COVID Hospital (DCH): 
i. For cases clinically assigned as severe.
ii. Full hospital or a separate block in hospital. 
iii. Private hospitals also can be designated. 
iv. Hospitals to have ICUs, ventilator and beds with oxygen. 
v. Hospitals will have separate areas for suspect and confirmed cases. vi.These Facilities are referrals centers for CCCs and DCHCs.

description:
India, 11 March 2020, In exercise of powers conferred under 'The Haryana Epidemic Disease Act 1897, The Governor of Haryana is pleased to issue following regulations regarding COVID-19 (Corona Virus Disease 2019):
If a suspected cases of COVID-19 refuses admission or isolation, the officers authorized in section 3 of these regulations will have powers to forcefully admit and isolate such case for period of 14 days from the onset of symptoms or till the reports of Lab tests are received, or such period as may be necessary.

description:
India, 11 March 2020, In exercise of powers conferred under 'The Haryana Epidemic Disease Act 1897, The Governor of Haryana is pleased to issue following regulations regarding COVID-19 (Corona Virus Disease 2019):
If case of COVID-19 are reported from a defined geographic area such as village, town, ward, colony, settlement, the District Administration of the concerned district shall have the right to implement following containment measures, but not limited to these, in order to prevent spread of disease.
i. Sealing of geographical area.
ii. Barring entry and exit of population from the containment area.
iii. Closure of schools, offices and banning public gatherings.
iv. Banning vehicular movement in area.
v. Initiating active and passive surveillance of COVID-19 cases.
vi. Hospital isolation of all suspected cases.
vii. Designating any Government/ Building as containment unit for isolation of the cases.
viii. Staff of all Government departments will be at disposal of district administration of the concerned area for discharging the duty of containment measures. 
ix. Any other measure as directed by Health department Haryana.

Designating any Government/ Building as containment unit for isolation of the cases. viii. Any other measure as directed by Health department Haryana.

description:
COVID-19 Guidelines for Employers and employees of Chandigarh Administration.
What to do if an employee is suspected of showing symptoms of COVID-19. 
• For the suspected patient 
If an employee shows some symptoms of COVID-19 at office, the unwell person should be removed to an area away from other people. Effort should be made to isolate him behind a closed door and windows should be opened for ventilation. He should avoid touching people, surfaces and objects and be advised to cover his mouth and nose with a disposable tissue/ handkerchief when he coughs or sneezes. If he doesn't have any disposable tissues/ handkerchief available, he should cough and sneeze into the crook of his elbow. If he needs to go to the bathroom while waiting for medical assistances, he should use a separate bathroom if available. If the employee is suspected, then the Department of Health should be informed for evaluation of the employee and if symptomatic, should be isolated in hospital and sampling should be done. 
• For other employees 
While they wait for an Ambulance/ Medical help to arrive, they should remain away from the suspected patient.
type_text: What to do if an employee is suspected of showing symptoms of COVID-19.  • For the suspected patient  If an employee shows some symptoms of COVID-19 at office, the unwell person should be removed to an area away from other people. Effort should be made to isolate him behind a closed door and windows should be opened for ventilation. He should avoid touching people, surfaces and objects and be advised to cover his mouth and nose with a disposable tissue/ handkerchief when he coughs or sneezes. If he doesn't have any disposable tissues/ handkerchief available, he should cough and sneeze into the crook of his elbow. If he needs to go to the bathroom while waiting for medical assistances, he should use a separate bathroom if available. If the employee is suspected, then the Department of Health should be informed for evaluation of the employee and if symptomatic, should be isolated in hospital and sampling should be done.  • For other employees  While they wait for an Ambulance/ Medical help to arrive, they should remain away from the suspected patient.

description:
India, 17 March 2020, COVID-19 Guidelines for Employers and employees of Chandigarh Administration.
What to do if a confirmed COVID-19 person has recently been to your Office. The senior officials should contact the Health Department Team to discuss the case, identify people who have been In contact with the affected person and seek advice on any actions or precautions that should be taken. The following may have to be isolated, as per medical advice: 
• Any employee in close face-to-face or touching contact of the confirmed case
 • Anyone who has cleaned up any bodily fluids of the confirmed case without wearing protective equipment such as gloves and face mask. Cleaning of surfaces, floors, door knobs and railings should be done and home quarantine should be advised to persons coming in close contact
type_text: India, 17 March 2020, COVID-19 Guidelines for Employers and employees of Chandigarh Administration. What to do if a confirmed COVID-19 person has recently been to your Office. The senior officials should contact the Health Department Team to discuss the case, identify people who have been In contact with the affected person and seek advice on any actions or precautions that should be taken. The following may have to be isolated, as per medical advice:  • Any employee in close face-to-face or touching contact of the confirmed case  • Anyone who has cleaned up any bodily fluids of the confirmed case without wearing protective equipment such as gloves and face mask. Cleaning of surfaces, floors, door knobs and railings should be done and home quarantine should be advised to persons coming in close contact

description:
In continuation of this Administration's letter No. 28/65-IH(7)- 2020/4080 dated 18.03.2020, the employers and employees of the Chandigarh Administration should follow the following guidelines on COVID-19 to tackle the epidemic like situation being laced in the country:-
a) The visit of general public/citizens to the offices during usual visiting hours from 12.00 noon to 01.00 pm is hereby kept in abeyance.
b) The public dealing departments/offices are advised to dispose of public work quickly so that public may not be forced to visit offices. The public may be advised not to visit public offices for their work till further order and can contact officers through email/telephone.

description:
20 March 2020, Restriction on public dealing- regarding.
To contain the spread of Novel corona virus (Covid-19) some preventive steps are required to be taken by all the departments in the respect of public dealings. In this regard Government has decided that-
a) Public access to important government offices such as District and State Secretariats shall be restricted by all Departments/offices. In exceptional circumstances, controlled and regulated access shall be permitted. 
b) Departments shall provide a telephone number for general public so that they can seek any service during office hours.
type_text: Restriction on public dealing- regarding. To contain the spread of Novel corona virus (Covid-19) some preventive steps are required to be taken by all the departments in the respect of public dealings. In this regard Government has decided that- a) Public access to important government offices such as District and State Secretariats shall be restricted by all Departments/offices. description: India, To restrict movement of unorganized labourers, The Union Home Secretory, dated 27 March 2020 addressed to the Chief Secretory has emphasized that facilities for providing food and shelter to migrant labourers and homeless is area of concern. Housed in community centers, barat ghars, jhanj ghars, dharamshalas, panchayat ghars, schools, college etc. where there is proper arrangement of toilets and drinking water. While settling them in these temporary shelter for period of lockdown it must be ensured that social distancing norms should strictly followed. They should be provided two meals a day in the form of cooked food packets or dry ration, if there is cooking facility in such shelters.

description: The Government of Karnataka, India on April 1st 2020 announced that it would use the portable public distribution system (PDS) to ensure that migrant workers working in Karnataka, who posses PDS cards issued by their native states or any other state within the country, will receive two months (April and May) worth of food, with the hope that it will prevent them from returning home due to food shortage.

description:
India, 1 April, 2020, Strengthening of COVID-19 Surveillance Activities at each level 
With reference to the subject cited above. 
In view of the evolving situation of COVID-19 in the Country & State and prevailing situation in other countries, there are high chances of further transmission of COVID-19. Therefore, it is of utmost importance to ensure that a robust surveillance system is in place in the District. For this, IDSP team should only be dedicatedly engaged in only surveillance work i.e. contact tracing, follow-up of lab samples, planning/review of containment measures etc. As you were informed earlier vide Order No. 46/4/2020-5HBII dated 09.03.2020 that State Govt. has constituted various committees/teams comprising of Directors/Dy. Directors along with their State teams for supervision and monitoring of activities being undertaken for containment of COVID-19.

description: India, 11 April, 2020, Under the Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Anna Yojna, the Government of India is providing 5 kg wheat per member per month and 1 kg pulse per family per month for 3 months (April, May and June, 2020) to the registered beneficiaries under NFSA free of cost. The Chandigarh Administration has decided to distribute 3 months food grains in one go i.e. 15 kg Wheat per persons and 03 kg Pulses per family to all registered beneficiaries as Priority Households and AAY households under DBT Scheme for food grains as per provisions of NFSA free of cost at their doorstep. This is in addition to the food subsidy already made available in the bank accounts of the registered beneficiaries.

description:
As per the revolving situation, with the surge in the number of cases there is a need of hour to analyze infrastructure updation and infrastructure gap analysis by updating
 COVID portal. In reference to the above, Government of India has issued guidelines which are attached herewith as a power point presentation to analyze case load and hearth care infrastructure' forecasting over a period of time, infrastructure capacity gap analysis and information regarding data updation in COVlD portal with district login access. Under signed have been directed to issue directions that your respective districts should start using the above mention tools. (i)Tool 1: Healthcare Infrastructure Gap analysis tool at peak Load: for infrastructure planning at maximum case load in a State or District/City,
(ii) Tool 2: Case load and Healthcare infrastructure forecasting over a
period of time: for forecasting number of cases based on the historical trend or assumed growth rate of confirmed cases and analyze infrastructure sufficiency over a period of time. At the operational level, the tool can be used at the state level and district level for estimating the requirement of infrastructure as the situation demands' since there is known lead line required for creation of beds, especially ICU beds, it is encouraged that the, tool be used at least twice a week to anticipate any surge demands as per the increase in total number: of confirmed cases' such tools can significantly augment.

description:
India, 20 April, 2020, regarding fixation of package rates of COVID-19 treatment in Private Medical Colleges and Hospitals of Haryana and to state the mode of payment for treatment of COVID-19 patients at private COVID4 9 hospitals. The patients/ suspects of COVID-19 are categorised into 4 categories and mode of payment for each of the categories is given below: 
1. Govt. Employees, Pensioners and their dependents-The Govt. Employees, Pensioners and their dependents would avail treatment as per the State Government' existing Reimbursement/ Cashless/ Empanelment policies, as the case may be. 
2. Persons having Govt./Private health insurance-The Persons having health insurance would avail treatment as per the terms & conditions of the individual policy. 3. Beneficiaries of Ayushman Bharat (AB) Scheme-The beneficiaries of AB scheme would avail treatment on cashless basis, as per the existing AB Scheme. The COVID hospital shall charge as per the existing AB scheme and submit bills directly to Ayushman Bharat, Haryana. 4. Persons, which do not come under all the above 3 categories-Such persons i.e. Patients/Suspects approaching Govt. Health facilities and then referred to COVID-19 hospitals (Government/Private), which do not fit in all 3 above mentioned categories, would avail treatment on cashless basis.

description: India, 1 May, 2020, Due to the spread of COVID-19 & nationwide lockdown, moreover in compliance with GOI notification vide V11011/01/2020 dated 17-04-2020, all the centres registered under PCPNDT Act, 1994 are directed to ensure that all its provisions are followed and all reports, records mandatory to be maintained/prepared as per the Law with due sincerity. All report submissions failing due in this period i.e. till 30-06-2020 shall be submitted by the 5th July, 2020. Wherever possible, electronic communication and electronic report filling should continue on an ongoing basis even before 30-06-2020.

description:
India, 1 May,2020, It is brought out for information of all that a portal for registration of stranded migrants, students, tourists etc has been developed by Chandigarh Administration. It is accessible from website of Chandigarh Administration http://Chandigarh.gov.in or can be accessed on the link http://admser.chd.nic.in/migrant Sh Rajiv Tewari has been made the Nodal Officer for Migrant Persons of other states stranded in Chandigarh and for Chandigarh residents stranded in other states. A stranded person has to fill in the basic details and submit after giving OTP received on his mobile. Alternatively, for the convenience of persons who are unable to do it themselves, the facility has been provided through Call Centre of Administration available on helpline
number 1800-180-2067 where the details can be provided telephonically (from 8.00 am to 8.00 pm) daily.

description: India, 3 May, 2020, As directed by Ministry of Home affairs vide order No. 40-3/2020-DM-I(A) dated 01-05-2020, the following activities will remain prohibited for period of two weeks w.e.f. 04 May, 2020, Further as directed by Ministry of Home Affairs, the following activities are permissible in RED ZONE- Constructional activities in urban areas: Only in situ construction (where workers are available on site and no workers are required to be brought in from outside) and construcional of renewable energy projects are permitted. All construction activities are permitted in rural areas.

description:
India, 11 March 2020, In exercise of powers conferred under 'The Haryana Epidemic Disease Act 1897, The Governor of Haryana is pleased to issue following regulations regarding COVID-19 (Corona Virus Disease 2019):
All person with a history of travel in last 14 days to a country or area from where COVID-19 has been reported, but do not have any symptoms of cough, fever, difficulty in breathing, should isolate themselves at home and cover their mouth and nose with a mask. Such persons must take precautions to avoid contact with any person including family members for last 14 days from the date of arrival from such areas.

description:
India, 24 April, 2020, State is doing many efforts. Major
steps/activities have been undertaken in the State for prevention & control of COVID-19.
In this regard, State is keeping a close eye on all persons coming from other Nations and States.
However it has come to light, that students who are resident of Haryana are coming back from Kota (Rajasthan) to their hometowns.
In order to be extra observant and to prevent the spread to COVID 19 ,
l. It is instructed to screen each and every student coming from above mentioned place and quarantine them as per protocol.
2. If any symptoms found among the students, same should be managed as per COVID 19 protocol and be reported on online portal.
3. They should be advised that in case, they develop any symptoms of Flu,he/she immediately report at the State helpline no. 8558893911/ District Helpline no. 1075, 108 and any other if available list attached )
4. Each student may be shared all Do's and Don'ts regarding quarantine
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Persons traveling outside the state of Assam in India and arriving back within 72 hours are not required to quarantine for 10 days if they fulfill these conditions: get a rapid antigen test upon return, if the test result is positive they will go through isolation per protocol, if the rapid antigen test result is negative, swab sample will be taken for RT-PCR test and person will be needed to stay in isolation until test result comes back. If test result is positive they will go through isolation per protocol, if negative they will not be required to isolate. The person is also required to follow hygiene and social distancing norms during their stay outside of Assam starting 30th October 2020. UPDATE: The original policy allowed people traveling outside of the state and returning within 96 hours to avoid quarantine if tested, it has been changed to 72 hours with the same protocols of negative testing.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
India, the Government of Haryana, in exercise of powers conferred under section 2,3 and 4 of the Epidemic Disease Act, 1897, has framed the Haryana COVID-I9 Regulation, 2020 for prevention and containment of Corona virus disease, 2019 (COVID-19).
Under section 2 of the Epidemic Disease Act, 1897 and
regulation made thereof , the Government of Haryana hereby notifies the following restriction until 31 March 2020:
All shops, commercial establishments, offices and factories, workshops, godowns etc. shall close their operations except for essential services mentioned in para below.
However, the following establishments providing essential services shall be excluded from the above restriction:
a)Bank/ATM.
b)Print, Electronic and Social Media.
c)Telecom & lnternet Services including IT & ITeS.
d)Postal services.
e)E-Commerce (delivery) of all essential goods including food, pharmaceutical and
medical equipment.
f)Food, Groceries, Milk, Bread, Fruit, Vegetable, Meat, Fish, Atta etc. and their transportation related activities and warehousing.
g)Take away/home delivery restaurants/ eateries.
h)Petrol pumps, LPG gas, Oil agencies, their godown Viand their transportation related activities.
institution_status: This type of business ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
In the territorial jurisdiction of the entire UT of Chandigarh in public interest w.e.f. 00:00 hrs on 23.03.2020 until 2400 hrs on March 31, 2020. These prohibitory measures will constrain the worker / employees of Private Establishments/Industries/Factories/Shops etc. to report for work. There may be such incidence that on this pretext, the employer may dispense with the services of the workers or may force the workers / employees to go on leave without wages/ salaries. 
Now, therefore, in exercise of the Epidemic Diseases, COVID-19 Regulation, 2020 issued by the Administrator, UT Chandigarh:- 
"The employees of private Establishments / Industries / Factories / Shops etc. (including temporary /casual /contractual /outsourced /daily-wage workers) who are required to stay at home in view of the orders of Chandigarh Administration shall be treated as 'on duty' and be paid in full".
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
19.03.2020 issued by the Government of India, Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions, Department of Personnel & Training, the following further instructions are issued for strict compliance:- 
i) Heads of Department (HoD) may ensure that 50% of Group B, C and D employees are required to attend office every day, and the remaining 50% staff should be instructed to work from home. All HODs are advised to draft a weekly roster of duty for Group B, C and D staff and ask them to attend office on alternate weeks. While deciding the roster for the first week, HoDs are advised to include officials who are residing in close proximity to their office or use their own transport to travel to the offices.

description:
India, the Government of Haryana, in exercise of powers conferred under section 2,3 and 4 of the Epidemic Disease Act, 1897, has framed the Haryana COVID-I9 Regulation, 2020 for prevention and containment of Corona virus disease, 2019 (COVID-19).
Under section 2 of the Epidemic Disease Act, 1897 and
regulation made thereof , the Government of Haryana hereby notifies the following restriction until 31 March 2020:
All shops, commercial establishments, offices and factories, workshops, godowns etc. shall close their operations except for essential services mentioned in para below.
However, the following establishments providing essential services shall be excluded from the above restrictions:
a) Government offices/ establishments as per the instructions of Chief Secretary Office.
b)Electricity, Water, Sewerage and Municipal Services.
c)Hospitals, Chemist shops, Optical stores, Pharmaceuticals manufacturing units including mask and sanitization material manufacturing units and their transportation related activities.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
India, 28 March 2020, DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC RELATIONS
CHANDIGARH ADMINISTRATION. It is brought out for information of all that to ensure that there is smooth supply of LPG Cylinders to residents/ Households in Chandigarh, the Administration has taken steps to steamline the process in the present situation.
Total 12180 LPG Cylinders were delivered by the Gas Agencies, wherein 8600 were supplied by IOCL, 1430 by HPCL and 2150 BPCL. The Administration assures all the residents that the supply of LPG Cylinders in the city will be maintained and there is no need to panic.
However, it is clarified that NO individual is allowed to visit any Gas agency for buying/ refilling LPG Cylinder. The residents can only place order telephonically for delivery of LPG Cylinder at their doorstep. In case anyone is found violating the provision, then strict legal action would be taken against both the individual and the shop owner as per law.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
U.T Chandigarh in exercise of powers vested with me under Section 144 of Cr.Pc. do hereby order as an emergency measure that there is prohibition on gathering of 5 or more person at Public Places Any breach of this order would invite action under Section 188 of Indian Penal Code 
In view of the emergent nature of the order, it is being issued Ex-parte and is addressed to the public in general.

description:
Ministry of Home Affairs issues advisory to all States/Union Territories to make adequate arrangements for migrant workers, students, etc from outside the States to facilitate Social Distancing for COVID-19. 

- The advisory suggests that in order to mitigate the situation for unorganized sector workers, particularly stranded migrant workers, States/UTs need to explore measures by involving various agencies, including NGOs, to provide food and shelter with basic amenities like clean drinking water, sanitation, etc. 
- MHA has also advised that States/ UTs need to ensure that hotels, rented accommodations, hostels, etc., continue to remain functional and delivery of essential items is streamlined, so that students, working women hostel inmates, etc. are allowed to continue in existing facilities while observing precautions.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: The state of Assam in India establishes a sop for cinemas and other public places. Proper crowd management required in parking lots, and outside the premises of cinemas/theaters/multiplexes. All social distancing guidelines should be followed at all times, including inside elevators, lobbies, restrooms, etc. Avoid overcrowding in these areas and food and drinks are also restricted from inside theatres. Staggered timings for shows should also be employed to avoid overcrowding. All payments are recommended to be online and non-contact, floor markers should also be used to follow social distancing.
